title: 109_hr5279
content: The Act titled "Oil and Gas Industry Antitrust Act of 2006" amends the Clayton Act to include a new section 28 regarding oil and natural gas. The Act "Oil and Gas Industry Antitrust Act of 2006" prohibits the refusal to sell, export, or divert petroleum, gasoline, or natural gas to increase prices or create shortages in a market. Considerations include increased costs and profits from exporting or diverting. The Act prohibits refusal to sell, export, or divert petroleum, gasoline, or natural gas to increase prices. Considerations include higher prices from exporting or diverting existing supplies. The Attorney General and the Chairman of the Federal Trade Commission will review whether section 7 of the Clayton Act should be amended in relation to petroleum, gasoline, and natural gas businesses. A report with recommendations and proposed legislation will be submitted to Congress within 270 days. Additionally, a study by the Government Accountability Office will be conducted. The term "covered consent decree" refers to a decree involving the Federal Trade Commission or Department of Justice, entered within 10 years, requiring divestitures, and related to petroleum, gasoline, or natural gas businesses. The Comptroller General of the United States must conduct a study on the effectiveness of divestitures under such decrees within 180 days of enactment. The Comptroller General will submit a report to Congress, the Federal Trade Commission, and the Department of Justice within 180 days of the enactment of the Act. The report will detail the findings of the study on divestitures required under covered consent decrees. Upon receiving the report, the Attorney General or the Chairman of the Federal Trade Commission will assess if further action is needed to restore competition or prevent a substantial lessening of competition resulting from the transactions studied. SEC. 5. JOINT FEDERAL AND STATE TASK FORCE. The Attorney General and the Chairman of the Federal Trade Commission will establish a joint Federal-State task force to investigate information sharing among businesses in the petroleum and natural gas industry. SEC. 6. NO OIL PRODUCING AND EXPORTING CARTELS. SEC. 6. NO OIL PRODUCING AND EXPORTING CARTELS. This section is known as the "No Oil Producing and Exporting Cartels Act of 2006" or "NOPEC." The Sherman Act is amended to address oil producing cartels. It is illegal for any foreign state, instrumentality, or agent to collectively limit oil production, set prices, or take actions that restrain trade for oil and petroleum products under the No Oil Producing and Exporting Cartels Act of 2006 (NOPEC). The No Oil Producing and Exporting Cartels Act of 2006 (NOPEC) prohibits foreign states from manipulating oil production, prices, or trade of oil and petroleum products in the United States. Foreign states violating this act are not immune to US court jurisdiction, and the act of state doctrine cannot be used to avoid legal action. The Attorney General can enforce this section in US district courts under antitrust laws. The Clayton Act is amended to include actions brought under section 8 of the Sherman Act, removing sovereign immunity for certain cases.
